title: Keep These Foods in Stock to Help You Manage Weight With HIV

sections.heading: Overview
content: If you've gained weight since starting HIV treatment, you're not alone. Many people see significant weight gain over the first two years of treatment.

Some HIV medications can cause weight gain. It's also possible that your body is regaining weight lost when the virus was more active, depleting your fat stores. Regardless of the cause, eating a healthy, nutrient-dense diet can help you control your weight.

When you keep your kitchen stocked with healthy items, you take the guesswork out of each individual food choice. You may also reduce your risk of reaching for the stuff that's going to throw you off track.
Add these types of foods to your shopping list.
Keep whole grains on hand rather than refined-grain counterparts like white bread, white rice, white pasta, and sugar-sweetened cereals. You can try fiber-rich staples like:
Whole grains have dietary fiber to help you feel full longer. That means you'll fill up on fewer calories and will be less likely to hunt for snacks between meals.
Non-starchy veggies that contain lots of fiber and water are lower in calories and carbohydrates. Fill up with fewer calories on veggies like:

Keep these veggies in your fridge, washed, peeled, chopped, and ready to go. Reach for them when you need a crunchy snack or a salad toss-in. Or lightly brush with olive oil and seasoning and roast them on a sheet pan.

sources: AIDS Reviews: "Weight gain in HIV-infected individuals using distinct antiretroviral drugs."
meta_description: The key to weight management success is always having a healthy food choice within reach. Make sure these foods, beverages, and spices are always in your kitchen.
